slideshow.caption: Tropical Glaciers are Disappearing
slideshow.longDescription: Even near the equator, tall mountains used to be capped with ice year round. But tropical glaciers could disappear entirely in a few decades , including those in the Sudirman Range on the Pacific island of New Guinea (shown with ice highlighted in blue in this false color image).

slideshow.caption: Arctic Ice Shrinks to Record Low
slideshow.longDescription: In 2012, the Arctic ice cap shrank to the smallest size ever recorded. If the polar ice caps continue to melt at the present rate, by 2100 there could be no Arctic ice at all during the summer.

slideshow.caption: Reservoir Dries in South Africa
slideshow.longDescription: The Theewaterskloof reservoir in South Africa was filled to capacity in 2014. By 2017, after three years of punishing drought, it had lost 73% of its water.

slideshow.caption: Record Wildfires in California
slideshow.longDescription: In 2017, California experienced its largest wildfire on record. The burned areas, highlighted in red, totaled nearly 1,140 square kilometers (440 square miles). Unburned areas are colored green.

slideshow.caption: Heavy Flooding in Cambodia
slideshow.longDescription: Roughly 3,000 square kilometers (1,200 square miles) of rice fields were destroyed by flooding of the Mekong and Tonlé Sap Rivers in 2013, affecting half a million people. Extreme floods are expected to increase as a warming climate raises sea levels and heavy rainfall increases in certain areas.

slideshow.caption: British Virgin Islands Stripped of Greenery by Hurricane Irma
slideshow.longDescription: Once covered in greenery, the British Virgin Islands were left brown and denuded by Hurricane Irma in 2017. Hurricanes could become more powerful as the climate warms.

slideshow.caption: Shrinking Glaciers in Switzerland
slideshow.longDescription: The Trift Glacier in Switzerland retreated 1.17 kilometers (0.7 miles) between 2006 and 2017.
slideshow.credit: James Balog and the Extreme Ice Survey

slideshow.caption: Bolivia’s Lake Poopó runs dry
slideshow.longDescription: In wet periods, Lake Poopó is Bolivia’s second largest lake, covering 3,000 square km (1,200 square miles). Already shrinking as water was diverted for mining and agriculture, the lake ran completely dry after a major drought in 2016.

slideshow.caption: Melting Ice in Greenland
slideshow.longDescription: In 2016, Greenland’s ice sheet became covered by rivers and lakes (visible in blue) earlier in the summer than in previous years. Formed from melting ice, the liquid water digs deep holes into the ice sheet, allowing the water to drain to the bottom of the ice sheet and into the ocean.

slideshow.caption: Massive Wildfires in Argentina
slideshow.longDescription: During a severe drought in 2017, about 10,000 square kilometers (4,000 square miles) were destroyed by numerous fires that spread through the dry Pampas region in Argentina. Burned areas are colored red.

slideshow.caption: Drought speeds reservoir loss in Iraq
slideshow.longDescription: The Qadisyah Reservoir in Iraq, which was already being drained for human use, lost water even faster following a drought in 2007. The Middle East could face increasing water shortages as the climate warms, runoff from snow melt is reduced and droughts become more frequent and severe.

slideshow.caption: Argentina Flooding damages soybean crop
slideshow.longDescription: Flooding from unusually heavy rain in 2016 and 2017 destroyed much of Argentina’s soybean crop. So many soybeans were destroyed that global prices rose worldwide in response to the reduced supply. Global warming could increase the severity of both floods and droughts

slideshow.caption: Hurricane Harvey Causes Flooding in Houston, Texas
slideshow.longDescription: In 2017, Hurricane Harvey dumped up to 122 cm (48 inches6) in the area around Houston, Texas, the largest single rainfall event in U.S. history.7 The storm displaced 30,000 people, destroyed 200,000 homes and businesses and caused $126 billion in property damage.8 Global warming could make such disasters more common.

slideshow.caption: Coral Bleaching in American Samoa
slideshow.longDescription: Vast areas of American Samoa’s coral reefs were damaged during a major global bleaching event in the Pacific Ocean in 2015. Temperature increases of even a few degrees can cripple entire reef systems. During a catastrophic 2016 heat wave, 30 percent of the coral in Australia’s Great Barrier Reef died.
